questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has a 20-year history of seizure disorder characterized by sudden-onset, periodic, jerking movements of both arms and lip-smacking. He has a history of intravenous cocaine use. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Examination shows gingival tissue covering the upper third of the teeth. There is bleeding of the gums when touched with a fine instrument. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures. However, the agent is associated with side effects such as hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, weight gain, and tremor rather than gingival hyperplasia.

B) CORRECT:

Phenytoin is used in the prophylaxis of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, as seen in this patient. The agent has many side effects, including gingival hyperplasia (drug-induced gingival overgrowth), hirsutism, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, megaloblastic anemia, nystagmus, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy. If possible, the drug should be discontinued and the patient should be advised to adhere to strict oral hygiene. If the gingival overgrowth does not improve or infection occurs, excision of excessive gingival tissue should be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures and can very rarely cause gingival hyperplasia. However, it is more typically associated with side effects such as nausea, skin rashes, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome. A different agent would be more likely to cause gingival hyperplasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures. However, the agent is associated with side effects such as diplopia, ataxia, hepatotoxicity, agranulocytosis, and aplastic anemia rather than gingival hyperplasia.

E) INCORRECT:

Topiramate can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures. However, the agent is associated with side effects such as sedation, weight loss, and kidney stones, rather than gingival hyperplasia.

F) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine can also cause gingival hyperplasia, as seen in this patient. However, the drug is primarily used in the treatment of arterial hypertension and Raynaud phenomenon. It would be an unlikely cause in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Phenobarbital can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures. However, the agent is associated with side effects such as sedation rather than gingival hyperplasia.

H) INCORRECT:

This patient has a history of cocaine use. However, chronic abuse of cocaine is associated with gingival recession rather than gingival hyperplasia.
questions.hint: This patient has generalized tonic-clonic seizures and signs of gingival hyperplasia.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of a generalized pruritic rash. He returned from a 3-day summer camp 1 week ago. During his time there, one child was sent home after being diagnosed with measles. Medical history is remarkable for asthma and a seizure disorder, which was diagnosed 6 weeks ago. Current medications include carbamazepine and an albuterol inhaler. His immunization records are unavailable. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 102/60 mm Hg. Examination shows facial edema and a diffuse rash over the face, trunk, and extremities. There is cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Carbamazepine is a common antiepileptic drug used for the treatment of both generalized seizures and focal seizures. In rare cases, it can also cause an acute drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DIHS), which may manifest with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy) and a diffuse morbilliform rash that progresses to confluent erythema with accentuation of the hair follicles, as well as facial edema. DIHS usually develops 2–8 weeks after initiating treatment and is also referred to as drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) as further symptoms include hematologic abnormalities (e.g., leukocytosis with eosinophilia), and internal organ involvement (e.g., hepatitis, pneumonitis, nephritis). Carbamazepine should be discontinued immediately and this patient should now transition to a different antiepileptic medication (e.g., valproic acid) to avoid life-threatening complications.

Other important side effects of carbamazepine include diplopia, vertigo, agranulocytosis, hyponatremia (due to SIADH), and dermatologic reactions (including Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis).
Image Description:

Erythematous, maculopapular lesions can be seen in a homogeneous distribution across this child's arm and upper chest (morbilliform rash).

In DRESS (Drug Rash/Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms) syndrome, this rash usually occurs after 2–8 weeks of drug treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute measles infection is characterized by fever, malaise, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (the 3 Cs of measles), and is followed by exanthem and generalized lymphadenopathy 2–4 days after the onset of fever. Serologic detection of measles-specific IgM antibodies and/or RT-PCR are the preferred tests to confirm acute measles infection. Although this patient may have been exposed to measles and may not be immunized, he lacks most of the hallmark features of the disease, and the timeline of his symptoms is not consistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

Photograph of a toddler

There is a generalized erythematous maculopapular exanthem. Some confluence is visible (e.g., on the upper thighs).

C) INCORRECT:

EBV serology is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis, which can manifest with fever, lymphadenopathy (usually cervical but can be generalized), and a rash (typically prompted by administration of aminopenicillin). However, the absence of other hallmark features of the disease such as fatigue, splenomegaly, and pharyngotonsillitis make this diagnosis unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Enlarged, inflamed tonsil (green overlay) with gray-white deposits (white outline) in a patient with infectious mononucleosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Penicillin would be indicated for scarlet fever, which classically manifests in patients aged 5–15 years with fever, pharyngeal erythema, and a scarlet-colored rash that is most pronounced in the groin, underarm, and elbow creases. Although this patient presents with a rash and fever, he lacks pharyngitis and his rash is diffuse rather than localized to intertriginous areas. Moreover, the facial edema and lymphadenopathy are not consistent with scarlet fever.
Image Description:

The typical scarlet-colored, fine, maculopapular exanthem of scarlet fever is seen on the right arm. Flushed cheeks and perioral pallor are also evident.

E) INCORRECT:

Rapid plasma reagin test (RPR) is a first-line test for syphilis, which primarily affects male individuals aged 20–29 years. Secondary syphilis can manifest with generalized lymphadenopathy and a polymorphic, copper-colored, maculopapular rash, which classically affects the soles and palms. Although this patient presents with a diffuse rash, it does not affect the palms or soles. Moreover, this patient lacks other findings of secondary syphilis (e.g., condyloma lata, myalgia). Finally, as an 11-year-old, this patient is unlikely to have a sexually transmitted infection.
Image Description:

Partially confluent and partially scaling red papules and macules of ∼2–5 mm diameter are visible on the palms and wrists.

This appearance is typical of secondary syphilis.

F) INCORRECT:

Administration of topical miconazole is indicated in fungal infections, such as tinea. Tinea is a superficial dermatophyte infection characterized by scaly patches and is classified based upon the affected region. It is caused by the dermatophytes Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton. It usually spreads by skin contact, contact with infected animals, or contaminated items. This patient presents with a diffuse rash that does not show scaly patches.
Image Description:

The face and arm show multiple, partially merging and erythematous lesions, some of which displaying centrally demarcated skin and the typical scaling and raised borders.

These findings are typical for a widespread dermatophyte infection, which can be transmitted via skin contact.

G) INCORRECT:

Rickettsial serologic studies are mainly useful for confirming the diagnosis of Rocky Mountain spotted fever after treatment has already begun. His outdoor exposure puts this patient at risk of tick-borne illnesses, including RMSF. Although RMSF presents with a diffuse rash, it usually starts at the extremities and progresses towards the trunk before progressing to pruritic papules and petechiae. Unlike in this patient, the face is only rarely involved. Besides fever, this patient does not have typical signs of the disease such as a history of tick bite, severe headache, malaise, abdominal pain, conjunctivitis, nausea, and/or vomiting, making RMSF an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent, macules are visible on this patient's forearm.

This rash is suggestive of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), a tick-borne disease caused by Rickettsia rickettsii bacteria. The distal extremities are usually affected first; the rash then spreads toward the proximal extremities and the trunk (the face, however, is usually spared).
questions.hint: Other complications related to this condition include elevated transaminases and eosinophilia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her first pregnancy and delivery were complicated by iron deficiency anemia and pregnancy-induced hypertension. She has had no routine prenatal care during this pregnancy but was diagnosed with oligohydramnios 4 weeks ago. The remainder of her medical history is not immediately available. A 2400-g (5.4-lb) female newborn is delivered vaginally. Examination of the newborn shows a short, mildly webbed neck and low-set ears. Ocular hypertelorism along with slanted palpebral fissures are noted. A cleft palate and hypoplasia of the nails and distal phalanges are present. There is increased coarse hair on the body and face. Which of the following best explains the clinical findings found in this newborn?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a collection of defects associated with maternal exposure to phenytoin and other hydantoins (e.g., fosphenytoin). Use of these medications interferes with folate metabolism which often induces a deficiency. Common features of fetal hydantoin syndrome include intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial abnormalities (e.g., cleft palate, hypertelorism, slanted palpebral fissures, and low-set ears), a short neck, limb defects (phalanx/fingernail hypoplasia), and excessive hair on the body and face. Other manifestations include cardiac anomalies (e.g., ventricular septal defect), ocular defects, hypospadias, and umbilical and inguinal hernias. Treatment is largely supportive and includes surgery to fix the cleft palate in addition to special education.

Fetal hydantoin syndrome does not typically manifest with neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida), which are usually seen in other types of folate deficiency and may occur as a result of maternal use of other anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine or valproate (see “Overview of antiepileptics to avoid during pregnancy” table).

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal posterior urethral valves cause urinary tract obstruction, which can lead to oligohydramnios and subsequent Potter sequence. Although Potter sequence can also cause craniofacial abnormalities, this syndrome is not associated with phalanx/nail hypoplasia or excessive hair growth. Additionally, posterior urethral valves almost exclusively occur in male newborns, making this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Infants born to diabetic mothers are at risk for caudal regression syndrome, a condition that causes abnormalities in the caudal portion of the body. This infant's features are largely confined to the face and thorax, making caudal regression syndrome unlikely. In addition, infants born to mothers with diabetes tend to have macrosomia, not growth restriction as seen here.
Image Description:

Lower abdomen and legs of a 2.5-year-old girl of a diabetic mother with poor glycemic control during pregnancy:

The hips and lower extremities appear hypoplastic and showed no muscular activity during the clinical examination. Orthopedic deformities included knees in a flexion contracture and equinovarus feet.

These findings are consistent with caudal regression syndrome. X-ray and MRI of the spine confirmed total sacral and partial lumbar vertebrae agenesis and termination of the spinal cord at T6.

D) INCORRECT:

Maternal alcohol intake can lead to fetal alcohol spectrum disorders, which can cause intrauterine growth restriction, hypoplastic nails, and facial dysmorphisms (e.g., ocular hypertelorism). However, fetal alcohol spectrum disorders typically do not cause cleft palate or excessive hair growth, making it an unlikely cause of this infant's symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Monosomy of the X chromosome leads to Turner syndrome, which may cause a webbed neck and low-set ears in a female newborn. However, Turner syndrome typically does not cause cleft palate, phalanx/fingernail hypoplasia, or excessive hair growth, making it an unlikely cause of this infant's symptoms.
questions.hint: This newborn's symptoms are most likely associated with maternal folate deficiency.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police officers due to inappropriate public behavior. He was at a pharmacy demanding to speak with the manager so he could discuss a business deal. Two weeks ago, he left his wife of 10 years and moved from another city in order to pursue his dreams of being an entrepreneur. He has not slept for more than 3-4 hours a night in the last 2 weeks. He has a history of bipolar disorder and diabetes. He has been hospitalized three times in the last year for mood instability. Current medications include lithium and insulin. Mental status examination shows accelerated speech with flight of ideas. His serum creatinine concentration is 2.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine by itself would probably not be a sufficient treatment for this patient. While this antiepileptic agent usually can be used alternatively to lithium for maintenance therapy in bipolar disorder, this patient is refractory to monotherapy with lithium and now needs a more intensive therapy for long-term management.

B) INCORRECT:

Clozapine is not indicated for the management of bipolar disorder. It is typically used for refractory schizophrenia.

C) INCORRECT:

While lithium and valproic acid can be given concurrently in patients with bipolar disorder, this combination is not indicated in this patient, as his renal failure is a contraindication for continued use of lithium.

D) CORRECT:

Combination therapy with a mood stabilizer (e.g., valproic acid) and an antipsychotic (e.g., quetiapine) is a first-line therapy option for maintenance treatment of refractory or severe bipolar disorder. The goal of maintenance therapy is to prevent future manic and depressive episodes and to reduce the risk of suicide. This actively manic patient with three hospitalizations within the last year has been refractory to monotherapy with the mood stabilizer lithium, and requires additional pharmaceutical management. In this case, lithium should be switched to a different mood stabilizer (i.e., valproic acid) as his labs indicate renal failure, which is a contraindication to lithium use. Further contraindications to lithium include severe dehydration, severe hyponatremia, and significant cardiovascular disease.

E) INCORRECT:

A combination of lithium and olanzapine would not be appropriate for this patient. While a combination therapy of a mood stabilizer and an antipsychotic is first-line therapy for the maintenance treatment of refractory or severe bipolar episodes, this patient's renal failure is a contraindication for continued use of lithium.
questions.hint: This patient with refractory bipolar disorder (i.e., accelerated speech with flight of ideas and decreased need for sleep despite lithium therapy) is presenting with an acute manic episode and has significant renal dysfunction (serum creatinine > 1.5 times baseline).

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of frequent episodes of unresponsiveness. During these episodes, he stares blankly, rhythmically nods his head, and does not respond to verbal stimulation for several seconds. Hyperventilation for 30 seconds precipitates an episode of unresponsiveness and head nodding that lasts for 7 seconds. He regains consciousness immediately afterward. An electroencephalogram shows 3-Hz spikes and waves. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Increased frequency of GABAA channel opening
Blockade of thalamic T-type calcium channels
Inhibition of presynaptic voltage-activated Ca2+ channels
Increased duration of GABAA channel opening
Inhibition of GABA reuptake into presynaptic neurons

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased frequency of GABAA channel opening is the mechanism of action of benzodiazepines. Benzodiazepines are the treatment of choice for status epilepticus. These drugs are also used for refractory cases of childhood absence epilepsy but are not used as first-line therapy.

B) CORRECT:

Blockade of thalamic T-type calcium channels is the mechanism of action of ethosuximide, which is the first-line therapy for seizure prophylaxis in patients with childhood absence epilepsy. T-type calcium channels are thought to be responsible for the rhythmic 3-Hz discharge seen on EEG during absence seizures.
Image Description:

Anticonvulsants act to either reduce excitatory signals (left) or amplify inhibitory signals (right).

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of presynaptic voltage-activated Ca2+ channels is the mechanism of action of gabapentin. This drug is contraindicated in patients with childhood absence epilepsy because it can precipitate absence seizures. Gabapentin is often used to treat focal seizures.

D) INCORRECT:

Irreversible inhibition of GABA transaminase is the mechanism of action of vigabatrin. This drug is contraindicated in patients with childhood absence epilepsy because it can precipitate absence seizures. Vigabatrin is used to treat refractory focal seizures. The agent is also the first-line therapy for West syndrome, especially if the underlying cause is tuberous sclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased duration of GABAA channel opening is the mechanism of action of barbiturates (e.g., phenobarbital). Phenobarbital is often used to treat seizures in neonates but is ineffective for absence seizures.

F) INCORRECT:

Blockade of voltage-gated Na+ channels is the mechanism of action of lamotrigine. This drug is a third-line therapy for seizure prophylaxis in patients with childhood absence epilepsy; another drug is more appropriate as first-line therapy. Several other anticonvulsant drugs also act on Na+ channels, including valproic acid (a second-line therapy that increases channel inactivation), carbamazepine (which blocks the channels but is not used because it can precipitate absence seizures), and phenytoin (which block the channels but is ineffective in treating absence seizures).

G) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of GABA reuptake into presynaptic neurons is the mechanism of action of tiagabine. This drug is contraindicated in patients with childhood absence epilepsy because it can precipitate absence seizures. Tiagabine is often used to treat focal seizures.
questions.hint: This boy has childhood absence epilepsy. Absence seizures typically manifest with episodes of staring, inattentiveness, and head nodding and can be triggered by hyperventilation. Patients typically maintain muscle tone during seizures and do not experience a postictal phase. The diagnosis is confirmed with EEG findings of a 3-Hz spike and wave pattern. First-line therapy is ethosuximide.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man with a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He is a known user of intravenous cocaine. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple hyperpigmented lines along the forearms. Oral examination shows marked overgrowth of friable, ulcerated gingival mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's oral examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Phenytoin is used in the prophylaxis of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, as seen in this patient. The agent has many side effects, including gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, megaloblastic anemia, nystagmus, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy. If possible, the drug should be discontinued and the patient should be advised to adhere to strict oral hygiene. If the gingival overgrowth does not improve or infection occurs, excision of excessive gingival tissue should be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine used to treat panic disorder and anxiety and is a common drug of abuse. It does not cause gingival hyperplasia. Common side effects include drowsiness, sedation, ataxia, memory impairment, and cognitive dysfunction.

Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment for convulsive status epilepticus, but diazepam, lorazepam, or midazolam are usually chosen instead of alprazolam.

C) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures. However, the agent is associated with side effects such as hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, weight gain, and tremor rather than gingival hyperplasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures and can very rarely cause gingival hyperplasia. However, it is more typically associated with side effects such as nausea, skin rashes, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome. A different agent would be more likely to cause gingival hyperplasia.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a history of cocaine use. However, chronic abuse of cocaine is associated with gingival recession rather than gingival hyperplasia.

F) INCORRECT:

Lacosamide is used in the treatment of focal seizures but not generalized seizures. It does not cause gingival hyperplasia. Common side effects of lacosamide include dizziness, ataxia, nausea, vomiting, diplopia, and blurred vision.

G) INCORRECT:

Cyclosporine can cause gingival hyperplasia, but it is used for transplant rejection prophylaxis and in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis, none of which apply to this patient. Cyclosporine can cause renal and hepatic toxicity; other common side effects are hypertension, headaches, hyperglycemia, and hirsutism.

H) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures. However, the agent is associated with side effects such as diplopia, ataxia, hepatotoxicity, agranulocytosis, and aplastic anemia rather than gingival hyperplasia.

If severe thrombocytopenia occurs in conjunction with aplastic anemia, patients can also present with bleeding gums.
questions.hint: Overgrowth of the gingival tissue is also known as gingival hyperplasia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. One month ago, he was diagnosed with a focal seizure and treatment with a drug that blocks voltage-gated sodium channels was begun. Today, he reports that he has not had any abnormal body movements, but he has noticed occasional double vision. His serum sodium is 132 mEq/L, alanine aminotransferase is 49 U/L, and aspartate aminotransferase is 46 U/L. This patient has most likely been taking which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Carbamazepine blocks voltage-gated sodium channels in neuronal membranes, which increases the seizure threshold and lowers neuronal excitability. Carbamazepine is commonly used as first-line treatment for focal seizures but is associated with a multitude of side effects, including diplopia, hepatotoxicity, and hyponatremia (probably due to associated SIADH), all of which are seen in this patient. Other possible side effects include Stevens-Johnson syndrome, ataxia, CYP-450 induction, and blood count abnormalities (agranulocytosis, aplastic anemia).

Blockage of voltage-gated sodium channels is also the mechanism of action of other anti-epileptic drugs, including valproic acid, lamotrigine, and topiramate.

B) INCORRECT:

Ethosuximide acts by inhibiting voltage-gated calcium channels in thalamic neurons and subsequently reducing neuronal excitability. Since ethosuximide is used only to treat absence seizures, administration would not be indicated in this patient. Moreover, side effects such as diplopia and hyponatremia would not be expected. Ethosuximide is rather associated with allergic skin reactions and nonspecific GI symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Levetiracetam is a relatively new antiepileptic drug with a mechanism of action that is not yet entirely understood. However, modulation of GABA receptors increased glutamate release, and inhibition of calcium channels have been implicated. Although levetiracetam is used as first-line treatment for focal seizures, side effects such as diplopia and hyponatremia would not be expected. Levetiracetam is rather associated with neuropsychiatric disturbances.

D) INCORRECT:

Gabapentin, most commonly administered for neuropathic pain, may also be used as second-line agent for focal seizures. However, it does not block voltage-gated sodium channels, instead inhibiting voltage-gated calcium channels. Moreover, the side effect profile of gabapentin does not match this patient's presentation; gabapentin is associated with ataxia, dry mouth, and somnolence, not hyponatremia and diplopia.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin acts by inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels but is primarily used as first-line treatment for tonic-clonic seizures and status epilepticus. Long-term administration for focal seizures is usually avoided due to its wide variety of possible side effects, including gingival hyperplasia and hirsutism. Diplopia, which is seen in this patient, may also occur but usually indicates toxicity and is therefore not a mere side effect. Furthermore, hyponatremia seen in this patient would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine acts by inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels and is commonly used as a first-line treatment for focal seizures. It can also cause hyponatremia and diplopia. However, diplopia and hyponatremia occur extremely rarely and are, typically, associated with a rapid dose escalation, acute toxicity, or coadministration of this drug with carbamazepine; all of which, are not seen here. Moreover, lamotrigine is more often associated with dermatologic side effects (ranging from mild exanthema to Stevens-Johnson syndrome), insomnia, dyspepsia, and rarely, nephrotoxicity or hepatotoxicity.

G) INCORRECT:

Topiramate can be used for focal seizures and exerts its antiepileptic properties both through blockage of voltage-gated sodium channels and increasing GABA action on neuronal cells. Even though this patient's diplopia could be a sign of new-onset glaucoma, which is in fact associated with topiramate treatment, hyponatremia and elevated transaminases would not be expected.
questions.hint: This drug is also the treatment of choice for trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.text: One week after starting a new medication, a 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a painful, blistering rash. She has a history of bipolar disorder. Her temperature is 39°C (102°F). Physical examination shows numerous coalescing bullae with epidermal detachment covering the face, trunk, and extremities. There are hemorrhagic erosions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. When lateral pressure is applied to healthy-appearing skin at the edge of a bulla, a blister starts to form. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is used with first-line mood stabilizers to treat refractory bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to quetiapine therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of quetiapine therapy include hyperprolactinemia, weight gain, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, prolonged QT interval, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is sometimes used in conjunction with other agents to treat refractory bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to topiramate therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of topiramate therapy include glaucoma, weight loss, nephrolithiasis, and cognitive impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. However, valproic acid is an extremely rare cause of SJS. More common adverse effects of valproic acid therapy include hepatic necrosis, pancreatitis, drug interactions due to CYP450 inhibition, weight gain, and gastrointestinal distress.

D) CORRECT:

Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. It is one of the most commonly implicated triggers of SJS. Most cases of SJS develop within 2–8 weeks of initiating the offending medication. The risk of developing SJS induced by lamotrigine therapy is greatest when high doses are used, so the initial dose should be low and increased slowly. In addition, about 10% of patients treated with lamotrigine develop a benign skin rash that is difficult to differentiate from early SJS; accordingly, all patients should be advised to discontinue lamotrigine therapy at the first sign of a rash. Other commonly implicated triggers of SJS include allopurinol, sulfamethoxazole, sulfa drugs, and phenobarbital. Other antiepileptic drugs, such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, and ethosuximide, can also cause SJS but are less frequently implicated than lamotrigine.

E) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to lithium therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of lithium therapy include gastrointestinal distress, neurologic symptoms (e.g., slurred speech, ataxia, hand tremors, seizures), nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, thyroid dysfunction (hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism), and teratogenesis (Ebstein anomaly).
questions.hint: This girl's fever, blistering rash, positive Nikolsky sign, and recent medication change are consistent with a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe form of this condition that involves > 30% of the skin.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 59 years 
Gender: F, self-identified 
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified 
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “This rash is killing me.”
History of Present Illness:

3-day history of a painful, blistering rash

rash started on trunk and spread to face and extremities
1-week history of fever and sore throat
was prescribed a new long-term medication 2 weeks ago by her primary care provider
no recent sick contacts

Past Medical History:

type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by peripheral neuropathy
hypertension
hyperlipidemia
bipolar disorder
breast cancer treated with total mastectomy

Medications:

atorvastatin
captopril
dulaglutide
lamotrigine
letrozole
metformin
over-the-counter ibuprofen prn for fever and sore throat

Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

father: type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension
maternal grandmother: breast cancer diagnosed age 56 years 

Psychosocial History:
does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs 
Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


39.0 °C(102.2°F)
98/min
16/min
132/88 mm Hg
96% on RA

175 cm(5 ft 9 in)

100 kg(220 lb)
32.5 kg/m2



Appearance: appears uncomfortable
Skin: numerous coalescing bullae with epidermal detachment on the face, trunk, and extremities; a new blister starts to form when lateral pressure is applied to healthy-appearing skin at the edge of an existing bulla
HEENT: hemorrhagic erosions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa; conjunctival injection
Neck: no jugular venous distention
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm
Abdominal: soft, nontender, nondistended
Neurologic: fully oriented


Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced pemphigus due to thiol-containing drugs (e.g., captopril) typically manifests as pemphigus foliaceus. This condition can result in a blistering rash and a positive Nikolsky sign but, unlike pemphigus vulgaris, does not involve the mucosa. Moreover, neither pemphigus vulgaris nor pemphigus foliaceus is associated with a prodromal fever. ACE inhibitors (e.g., captopril) are not a known cause of SJS. Thiazides, which are structurally similar to antibacterial sulfonamides, were once believed to cause SJS but recent studies have shown no significant link.
Image Description:

The erythematous skin of the face is covered with yellowish scales and crusts; the lips appear unaffected.

The diagnosis of pemphigus foliaceus was confirmed via skin biopsy and positive direct immunofluorescence. Unlike pemphigus vulgaris, which affects only the lower epidermal layers, including of the mucous membranes, but causes neither scaling nor crusting, pemphigus foliaceus is a blistering disease of the upper epidermal layers, resulting in the features seen here but not affecting the mucous membranes.

B) INCORRECT:

Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Typical adverse effects include hot flashes, night sweats, vaginal dryness, myalgias, arthralgias, and an increased risk of osteoporosis. Letrozole is not a known cause of SJS.

C) INCORRECT:

NSAID-induced SJS usually occurs with oxicam NSAIDs (e.g., piroxicam, tenoxicam) rather than with ibuprofen. In addition, ibuprofen was not started until after the onset of prodromal symptoms (e.g., fever, sore throat) of SJS.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (e.g., dulaglutide) can rarely cause serious type 1 hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis) but have not been identified to be a cause of SJS. Sulfonylureas, which are structurally similar to antibacterial sulfonamides, were once believed to cause SJS but recent studies have shown no significant link.

E) INCORRECT:

Adverse effects of statins (e.g., atorvastatin) include headaches, gastrointestinal symptoms, elevated LFTs, myalgias, and statin-associated myopathy. Statins are not a known cause of SJS.

F) CORRECT:

Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. It is one of the most commonly implicated triggers of SJS. Most cases of SJS develop within 2–8 weeks of initiating the offending medication. The risk of developing SJS induced by lamotrigine therapy is greatest when high doses are used, so the initial dose should be low and increased slowly. In addition, about 10% of patients treated with lamotrigine develop a benign skin rash that is difficult to differentiate from early SJS; accordingly, all patients should be advised to discontinue lamotrigine therapy at the first sign of a rash. Certain antiepileptic drugs such as phenytoin, phenobarbital, and carbamazepine can also cause SJS but are less frequently implicated than lamotrigine. Other commonly implicated triggers of SJS include certain sulfa drugs (e.g., sulfamethoxazole, sulfasalazine), certain antiretroviral drugs (e.g., nevirapine), oxicam NSAIDs (e.g., piroxicam), and allopurinol.
questions.hint: This patient's prodromal fever, blistering rash, positive Nikolsky sign, and recent medication change are consistent with a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe form of this condition that involves > 30% of the skin.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and trigeminal neuralgia presents for a routine physical examination. She reports moderate fatigue, difficulty sleeping, and knee pain (all as chronic issues). She denies any recent infections. Her facial pain has improved substantially since her neurologist started her on carbamazepine 6 weeks ago, but her energy level remains poor. Her other medications are acetaminophen, metformin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. On average, she drinks one alcoholic beverage 2 days per week.
Physical examination reveals no obvious abnormalities.
Routine blood testing is notable for a leukocyte count of 3200 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), with an absolute neutrophil count of 1400 per mm3 (1900–7600) and an otherwise normal differential, a hemoglobin level of 16.0 g/dL (12.0–16.0), and a platelet count of 327,000 per mm3 (150,000–350,000). Pathology review of her peripheral smear shows no obvious abnormalities. A review of her electronic medical record reveals that her leukocyte counts during the past 10 years have generally ranged from 5000 to 9000 per mm3 .
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in evaluating this patient’s leukopenia?

choices.text: Testing for HIV, hepatitis B and C viruses, vitamin B12, folic acid, and copper
Ongoing observation with serial hematologic surveillance
Sequential discontinuation of medications, beginning with carbamazepine, and monitoring for improvement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Viral infections (HIV, hepatitis B or C) and nutritional deficiencies (vitamin B12, folic acid, and, in rare instances, copper) can be associated with leukopenia, but screening for all of these entities simultaneously is unnecessary when there is a more plausible alternative. Such testing is warranted if the leukopenia persists or if other risk factors are present (e.g., excess alcohol use, illicit drug use, or sexual intercourse without condoms).

B) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry of the peripheral blood is useful when assessing a large population of abnormal cells in the blood, such as peripheral lymphocytosis, atypical lymphocytosis, or peripheral blasts, but it is not useful in the evaluation of leukopenia with an otherwise normal differential. Such testing is costly and unlikely to be of value.

C) CORRECT:

Leukopenia is frequently encountered in the outpatient setting and is often identified incidentally on screening laboratory tests. The differential diagnosis is broad and includes primary bone-marrow disorders, various infections, autoimmune conditions, medication-related causes, and nutritional deficiencies. Patients with leukopenia often present with a variety of somatic complaints that may or may not be related to their hematologic values. The challenge for the primary care provider is to decide which values should prompt additional evaluation and treatment.

Nearly any medication can be associated with leukopenia, but in this case, carbamazepine raises the greatest suspicion, because it was added to the patient’s regimen only recently and her leukocyte counts had been normal for years before then. Although carbamazepine is often used as an antiepileptic, it has a wide variety of other uses, including as a treatment for bipolar disorder and trigeminal neuralgia. Carbamazepine is known to be associated with leukopenia (less than 10% of the time) and, in rare cases, can result in aplastic anemia. The precise mechanism for these effects is unclear but may relate to direct inhibition of granulopoiesis. Generally, patients with leukopenia who are asymptomatic and have an absolute neutrophil count >1000 per mm3 (as this patient does) can be monitored closely with serial testing of leukocyte counts. Often, these counts will spontaneously recover over time; if they do not, the clinician may consider reducing the dose of the drug or discontinuing it in consultation with the patient’s neurologist.

Although no particular test can confirm that a certain medication is the cause of this patient’s leukopenia, at this point, serial discontinuation of her medications is unnecessary and may be harmful.

Key learning point: Mild, asymptomatic carbamazepine-induced leukopenia and neutropenia are best managed by ongoing observation with serial hematologic surveillance.

D) INCORRECT:

Although no particular test can confirm that a certain medication is the cause of this patient’s leukopenia, at this point, serial discontinuation of her medications is unnecessary and may be harmful.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a bone-marrow examination is a reasonable part of a leukopenia evaluation, it would be premature after a single, mildly low leukocyte count in a patient without any constitutional symptoms who has a far more likely explanation for her leukopenia — the recent addition of carbamazepine to her medication regimen. Warning signs that would make a bone-marrow examination more pertinent include a persistent absolute neutrophil count <1000 per mm3, constitutional symptoms (fevers, night sweats, unintentional weight loss), recurrent infections, adenopathy, organomegaly, and evidence of abnormal cells on a peripheral smear.

questions.text: One week after starting a new medication, a 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a painful, blistering rash. She has a history of bipolar disorder. Her temperature is 39°C (102°F). Physical examination shows numerous coalescing bullae with epidermal detachment covering the face, trunk, and extremities. There are hemorrhagic erosions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. When lateral pressure is applied to healthy-appearing skin at the edge of a bulla, a blister starts to form. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is used with first-line mood stabilizers to treat refractory bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to quetiapine therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of quetiapine therapy include hyperprolactinemia, weight gain, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, prolonged QT interval, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is sometimes used in conjunction with other agents to treat refractory bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to topiramate therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of topiramate therapy include glaucoma, weight loss, nephrolithiasis, and cognitive impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. However, valproic acid is an extremely rare cause of SJS. More common adverse effects of valproic acid therapy include hepatic necrosis, pancreatitis, drug interactions due to CYP450 inhibition, weight gain, and gastrointestinal distress.

D) CORRECT:

Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. It is one of the most commonly implicated triggers of SJS. Most cases of SJS develop within 2–8 weeks of initiating the offending medication. The risk of developing SJS induced by lamotrigine therapy is greatest when high doses are used, so the initial dose should be low and increased slowly. In addition, about 10% of patients treated with lamotrigine develop a benign skin rash that is difficult to differentiate from early SJS; accordingly, all patients should be advised to discontinue lamotrigine therapy at the first sign of a rash. Other commonly implicated triggers of SJS include allopurinol, sulfamethoxazole, sulfa drugs, and phenobarbital. Other antiepileptic drugs, such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, and ethosuximide, can also cause SJS but are less frequently implicated than lamotrigine.

E) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to lithium therapy have not been reported. More common adverse effects of lithium therapy include gastrointestinal distress, neurologic symptoms (e.g., slurred speech, ataxia, hand tremors, seizures), nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, thyroid dysfunction (hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism), and teratogenesis (Ebstein anomaly).
questions.hint: This girl's fever, blistering rash, positive Nikolsky sign, and recent medication change are consistent with a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe form of this condition that involves > 30% of the skin.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man with a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple hyperpigmented lines along the forearms. Oral examination shows marked overgrowth of friable, ulcerated gingival mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's oral examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Phenytoin is used in the prophylaxis of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, as seen in this patient. The agent has many side effects, including gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, megaloblastic anemia, nystagmus, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy. If possible, the drug should be discontinued and the patient should be advised to adhere to strict oral hygiene. If the gingival overgrowth does not improve or infection occurs, excision of excessive gingival tissue should be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures. However, the agent is associated with side effects such as hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, weight gain, and tremor rather than gingival hyperplasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures and can very rarely cause gingival hyperplasia. However, it is more typically associated with side effects such as nausea, skin rashes, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome. A different agent would be more likely to cause gingival hyperplasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Lacosamide is used in the treatment of focal seizures but not generalized seizures. It does not cause gingival hyperplasia. Common side effects of lacosamide include dizziness, ataxia, nausea, vomiting, diplopia, and blurred vision.

E) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures. However, the agent is associated with side effects such as diplopia, ataxia, hepatotoxicity, agranulocytosis, and aplastic anemia rather than gingival hyperplasia.

If severe thrombocytopenia occurs in conjunction with aplastic anemia, patients can also present with bleeding gums.
questions.hint: Overgrowth of the gingival tissue is also known as gingival hyperplasia.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to frequent spells where she suddenly stops talking, appears to stare for several seconds, and then resumes her activity without confusion. Her teacher reports these episodes occur multiple times a day, and the child has no memory of them. Physical examination is normal. Serum studies and neuroimaging are normal (see report).
Electroencephalography: Generalized 3-Hz spike-and-wave discharges
Which medication is the most appropriate initial therapy for her condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ethosuximide is the first-line treatment for typical absence seizures, especially in children. It works by inhibiting T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons, which are crucial in generating the 3-Hz spike-and-wave discharges seen on electroencephalography. This inhibition reduces the abnormal thalamocortical oscillations responsible for the brief lapses in consciousness characteristic of absence seizures. The clinical presentation of brief staring episodes without postictal confusion, along with the classic EEG pattern, confirms the diagnosis and supports the use of ethosuximide.

Key learning point: Ethosuximide is the first-line treatment for absence seizures, characterized by brief staring spells and 3-Hz spike-and-wave EEG patterns.

B) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid is a broad-spectrum antiepileptic effective for various seizure types, including absence seizures. However, due to its adverse effects, such as hepatotoxicity and weight gain, it is not the preferred initial treatment for isolated absence seizures. It is more suitable for patients with multiple seizure types, necessitating a broad-spectrum approach.

C) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine is used for focal seizures due to its action on voltage-gated sodium channels. It is not effective for absence seizures, which involve abnormal thalamocortical oscillations. In fact, carbamazepine may exacerbate absence seizures, making it inappropriate for this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine is a broad-spectrum antiepileptic that inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels. While useful for various seizure types, it does not directly target T-type calcium channels, which are involved in absence seizures. It is generally reserved for cases with multiple seizure types, not isolated absence seizures.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with epilepsy on valproic acid is now 10 weeks pregnant and worried about congenital anomalies. Which defect is most strongly associated with her medication?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polydactyly, involving extra digits, is not typically associated with valproic acid exposure. The drug's teratogenic effects are more related to neural tube defects due to interference with folate metabolism, rather than limb development anomalies.

B) CORRECT:

Valproic acid is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects, such as spina bifida, due to its interference with folate metabolism during early embryogenesis. This disruption affects the closure of the neural tube, leading to defects like spina bifida, where the vertebral arches fail to fuse completely. This teratogenic effect underscores the importance of folate supplementation and careful management of antiepileptic therapy in women of childbearing age.

Key learning point: Valproic acid use during pregnancy is associated with a markedly increased risk of neural tube defects in the fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Cleft lip is not primarily associated with valproic acid exposure. Valproic acid's teratogenic effects mainly involve neural tube defects due to its impact on folate metabolism, rather than craniofacial anomalies like cleft lip.

D) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid is not primarily linked to cardiac defects such as coarctation of the aorta. Its teratogenic effects are more strongly associated with neural tube defects due to interference with folate metabolism during neural tube closure.

questions.text: You are seeing a 16-year-old girl who is brought to the emergency department by her mother with a painful, blistering rash that developed one week after starting a new medication. She has a history of bipolar disorder. Her temperature is 39°C. On examination, there are numerous coalescing bullae with epidermal detachment involving the face, trunk, and extremities. Hemorrhagic erosions are present on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. When lateral pressure is applied to healthy-appearing skin at the edge of a bulla, a blister forms. Which one of the following drugs is most likely responsible for her current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine is a second-generation antipsychotic that is commonly used as a first-line treatment for acute mania and bipolar depression. There have been no reported cases of SJS associated with quetiapine therapy. More common adverse effects of quetiapine therapy include weight gain, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, prolonged QT interval, extrapyramidal symptoms, and, in some cases, hyperprolactinemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. However, valproic acid is an extremely rare cause of SJS. More common adverse effects of valproic acid therapy include weight gain, gastrointestinal distress, and drug interactions due to CYP450 inhibition. Pancreatitis and hepatic necrosis are other rare but serious side effects of valproic acid.

C) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a mood stabilizer commonly used to treat bipolar disorder. Although extremely rare, it can lead to SJS. However, another medication is a more frequent cause of SJS. More common adverse effects of lithium therapy include gastrointestinal distress and neurological symptoms (e.g., slurred speech, ataxia, hand tremors, seizures). Rare adverse effects include nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, thyroid dysfunction (hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism), and teratogenic effects (e.g., Ebstein anomaly).

D) CORRECT:

Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. It is one of the most commonly implicated triggers of SJS. Most cases of SJS develop within 2–8 weeks of initiating the offending medication. The risk of developing SJS induced by lamotrigine therapy is greatest when high doses are used, so the initial dose should be low and increased slowly. In addition, about 10% of patients treated with lamotrigine develop a benign skin rash that is difficult to differentiate from early SJS; accordingly, all patients should be advised to discontinue lamotrigine therapy at the first sign of a rash. Other commonly implicated triggers of SJS include allopurinol, sulfamethoxazole, sulfa drugs, and phenobarbital. Other antiepileptic drugs, such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, and ethosuximide, can also cause SJS but are less frequently implicated than lamotrigine.

Key learning point: Lamotrigine is a common drug trigger for Stevens-Johnson syndrome, which presents with mucocutaneous blistering and epidermal detachment within weeks of starting therapy.
questions.hint: This girl's fever, blistering rash, positive Nikolsky sign, and recent medication change are consistent with a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe form of this condition that involves > 30% of the skin.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man with a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he has multiple hyperpigmented lines along his forearms. Oral examination reveals marked overgrowth of friable, ulcerated gingival mucosa. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his oral findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lacosamide is utilized as either a monotherapy or an adjunctive therapy for managing focal seizures in adults with epilepsy. It does not cause gingival hyperplasia. Common side effects of lacosamide include dizziness, ataxia, nausea, vomiting, diplopia, and blurred vision.

B) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures. However, the agent is associated with side effects such as hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, weight gain, and tremor rather than gingival hyperplasia.

C) CORRECT:

Phenytoin is used in the prophylaxis of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, as seen in this patient. The agent has many side effects, including gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, megaloblastic anemia, nystagmus, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy. If possible, the drug should be discontinued and the patient should be advised to adhere to strict oral hygiene. If the gingival overgrowth does not improve or infection occurs, excision of excessive gingival tissue should be considered.

Key learning point: Phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug commonly associated with gingival hyperplasia as a notable side effect.

D) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures. However, the agent is associated with side effects such as diplopia, ataxia, hepatotoxicity, agranulocytosis, and aplastic anemia rather than gingival hyperplasia.

If severe thrombocytopenia occurs in conjunction with aplastic anemia, patients can also present with bleeding gums.

E) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine can be used to treat tonic-clonic seizures and can very rarely cause gingival hyperplasia. However, it is more typically associated with side effects such as nausea, skin rashes, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome. A different agent would be more likely to cause gingival hyperplasia.
questions.hint: Overgrowth of the gingival tissue is also known as gingival hyperplasia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with a history of epilepsy, bipolar disorder, and hypertension is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at home with a note apologizing to his wife for the overdose and outlining funeral plans. He takes lamotrigine, lisinopril, valproic acid, and sertraline. On arrival, vital signs are BP, 90/58 mm Hg; P, 118; R, 10; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); SpO₂, 88% on room air. He is obtunded with sluggish pupils and has a mild tremor. Laboratory results: glucose 98 mg/dL, sodium 140 mEq/L, potassium 4.0 mEq/L, bicarbonate 18 mEq/L, ammonia 110 mcg/dL (normal 10–80 mcg/dL), and AST 85 U/L. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine overdose can produce CNS depression and seizures but does not typically cause hyperammonemia or hepatotoxicity. The combination of respiratory depression, hypotension, and elevated ammonia suggests another agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Sertraline toxicity may cause mild agitation, tremor, or serotonin syndrome when combined with other serotonergic drugs, but it does not produce the metabolic abnormalities seen here, including hyperammonemia and transaminase elevation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — Valproic acid toxicity leads to CNS depression, respiratory insufficiency, hyperammonemia, and hepatic injury due to inhibition of urea cycle metabolism. Management is primarily supportive with airway protection, IV fluids, and early consultation with a poison control center. L-carnitine therapy is indicated in significant toxicity with altered mental status, hepatotoxicity, or markedly elevated ammonia levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril overdose may cause hypotension and mild hyperkalemia but does not lead to CNS depression, hepatic injury, or hyperammonemia. It cannot account for this patient’s neurologic and metabolic findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine overdose often presents with ataxia, nystagmus, and cardiac conduction delays such as QRS widening, none of which are described here. The metabolic profile and hyperammonemia point toward valproic acid as the cause.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe upper abdominal pain and nausea for six hours. She describes the pain as constant, radiating to her back, and associated with two episodes of nonbloody, nonbilious vomiting. She has bipolar disorder, for which she began a new medication regimen three weeks ago following a hospitalization for a manic episode. Medical history is remarkable for seasonal allergies. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Family history is unremarkable. She is alert and appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mm Hg. Examination shows mild epigastric tenderness without rebound or guarding. Laboratory studies show a serum amylase of 480 U/L and a lipase of 850 U/L. Liver function tests and serum triglyceride levels are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine is a first-generation anticonvulsant that can be used as a mood stabilizer for bipolar disorder. Although rare cases of pancreatitis have been reported in patients taking carbamazepine, it is not a well-established or common cause of this condition. Common adverse effects of carbamazepine include blood count abnormalities (e.g., agranulocytosis), Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.

B) CORRECT:

Valproic acid is a first-generation anticonvulsant that is commonly used as a mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder. It is a well-recognized cause of drug-induced acute pancreatitis, particularly in young adults and children. The onset of pancreatitis can occur within weeks to months of starting treatment. Other important adverse effects of valproic acid include tremor, alopecia, and teratogenicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine is a second-generation anticonvulsant that can be used as a mood stabilizer in the maintenance therapy of bipolar disorder, but it is not associated with pancreatitis. Important adverse effects of lamotrigine include immune-mediated skin reactions (e.g., Stevens-Johnson syndrome).

D) INCORRECT:

Lithium is a first-line mood stabilizer for bipolar disorder, but it is not associated with acute pancreatitis. Adverse effects of lithium include arginine vasopressin resistance, hypothyroidism, and chronic kidney disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Olanzapine is a second-generation antipsychotic that can be used for the maintenance therapy of bipolar disorder. While olanzapine can cause significant metabolic adverse effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia) and, rarely, severe hypertriglyceridemia, which can cause hypertriglyceridemia-induced pancreatitis, this patient has normal triglyceride levels and no evidence of metabolic syndrome, making olanzapine-induced pancreatitis unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of severe, radiating epigastric pain, vomiting, and elevated serum amylase and lipase is consistent with pancreatitis. The absence of other common causes of pancreatitis in this patient (e.g., gallstones, heavy alcohol use, hypertriglyceridemia), combined with the new treatment regimen for bipolar disorder, strongly suggests drug-induced pancreatitis.
